shared.shortDescription: A free and open source resume builder.

validation.dateRange: End Date must be later than Start Date.
validation.email: Must be a valid email address.

landing.slogan: All you need to do is just edit

features.heading: Friendly interface
features.text: Our website is built with the top criteria of being user-friendly, accessible and easy to use.

features.heading: Variety of Templates
features.text: We have researched and created countless CV templates with a variety of colors, layouts... which are suitable for many jobs.

features.heading: Deep level of customization
features.text: We allow you to customize templates with personal style like editing text size, font, color, layout and many more.

steps.heading: Pick a Template
steps.text: Here, we offer a lot of options for you. Choose a template that's user-friendly and relevant to your business.

steps.heading: Customize Template
steps.text: You can customize more details in your CV such as layout, color, text size... to suit your personality.

steps.heading: Fill in the blank
steps.text: Fill in your CV information, the information you fill in will be stored in real-time.

steps.heading: Download!
steps.text: And yes, it's free! You don't have to pay any cost once you've completed your CV. Now just click on the Download button and apply for the job.

dashboard.title: Dashboard
dashboard.helpText: You are going to be creating a new resume from scratch, but first, let's give it a name. This can be the name of the role you want to apply for, or if you're making a resume for a friend, you could call it Alex's Resume.

tour: Click here to name your CV
Choose a template that you like to make your CV look better
Click here to edit your personal information
When you finish, you just need to click here to download

work: Switch positions around the resume if some particular experiences are more relevant to a certain position you are applying for.
Include between 2-4 work experiences that are relevant to the job you are applying.
If you don't have that much work experience, try to give more attention to the Education, Projects and Skills sections.
In this section, you need to write how your current work experience makes you the ideal candidate for the position.
It is important that the tasks you list are not vague or too general, you must be specific about the particular tasks you have done.
education: Here you should include your school(s) and the courses that you took which are relevant to the position you are applying for.
Include courses that are relevant to your career objective or related to the job announcement.
Don't try and falsify things when it comes to your education. It goes without saying: if you exaggerate or lie about your education, somebody will eventually notice it.
skills: Read the job ad many times and understand what skills are sought by the employer before completing this section.
Here you should first include the specific skills you need for the job you are applying for.
If you did not include a dedicated section for Soft Skills, mention them here (e.g.: Self-motivation, Communication, Time Management, Flexibility, etc.).
Using industry-specific skills in your resume will enable you to pass through an applicant tracking system (ATS).
Search on the internet for the skills that are most needed in the industry you are applying for and list them on your resume if you think you possess them.
languages: Include the languages you know here and the level of your knowledge. Knowing an uncommon language can help you to stand out from other candidates.
projects: Try to include around 3-4 of the most relevant projects that you have worked on.
List the name of the project and a short description of what the project was about and the skills you have developed while working on it.
Do not just write the project name - instead, try to give also a summary of the project, what knowledge you applied and what skills you developed.
organizations: You should avoid mentioning organizations that indicate a religious affiliation, political identification, ethnicity or race.
You should avoid mentioning organizations that indicate a religious affiliation, political identification, ethnicity or race.
Make sure to include the full names of the organization because they can be used as keywords when a company is looking for potential candidates.
awards: Include here the certifications and licenses that you possess and could add value to the company. (e.g.: CPR, First Aid, Teaching, scuba diving, fitness certification, etc.).
Remember that in some professions, certifications carry as much weight as academic degrees.
For each certification include the certifying organization and also the type and area of specialization, and the date received.
interests: List your interests in case they coincide with the job/position you are applying for. You should be able to prove and talk about your interests if needed.
If for example your list “reading”, you should be prepared to talk about the last three-four books you read.
One of the best ways to grab the attention of employers is to include relevant information about your activities and interests outside of work.
Any number interests and activities can be professionally relevant, and they can showcase your potential for leadership, teamwork, and experience.
If you are a student sending out resumes for the first time, the activities in your resume can include community involvement activities, athletics, or participation in events.
If you are an older worker, include interests that will only benefit the particular job you are applying for.

toasts.formErrors: You might need to fill up all the required fields before submitting this form.
toasts.doesNotExist: The resume you were looking for does not exist anymore... or maybe it never did?
toasts.loadDemoData: Not sure where to begin? Try loading demo data to see what Reactive Resume has to offer.
toasts.printError: The cloud function is running into some trouble, please try again later or use the browser print feature.

import.heading: Import Your Resume
import.text: You can import your information from various sources like JSON Resume or your LinkedIn to autofill most of the data for your resume.

export.heading: Export Your Resume
export.text: Export your resume as a PDF to share with recruiters or a JSON that you will be able to import back onto this app on another computer.

share.heading: Share Your Resume
share.text: The link below will be accessible publicly if you choose to share it, viewers would see the latest version of your resume at any time.

loadDemoData.text: Unclear on what to do with a fresh blank page? Load some demo data to see how a resume should look and you can start editing from there.

resetEverything.text: Feels like you made too many mistakes? No worries, clear everything with just one click, but be careful if there are no backups.

settings.translate: If you would like to contribute by providing translations in your language, <1>please visit this link</1>.

dangerZone.heading: Danger Zone
dangerZone.text: If you would like to delete your account and erase all your resumes, it’s just one button away. Please be wary as this is an irreversible process.

donate.heading: Donate to Reactive Resume
donate.text: I try to do what I can, but if you found the app helpful, or you're in a better position than the others who depend on this project for their first job, <1>please consider donating as little as $5 to help keep the project alive</1> :)

bugFeature.heading: Bug? Feature Request?
bugFeature.text: Something halting your progress from making a resume? Found a pesky bug that just won't quit? Talk about it on the GitHub Issues section using the actions below.

appreciate.heading: Loved Reactive Resume?
appreciate.text: I never get tired of hearing stories of how this app helped people, and if it helped you, or you just found Reactive Resume to be an awesome tool, do let me know. You can reach out to me on my website.

sourceCode.heading: Source Code
sourceCode.text: Want to run the project from its source? Are you a developer willing to contribute to the open-source development of this project? Click the button below.

auth.loggedOutText: Reactive Resume needs to know who you are so it can securely authenticate you into the app and show you only your information. Once you are in, you can start building your resume, editing it to add new skills or sharing it with the world!
auth.loggedInText: Awesome. Now that you've authenticated yourself, we can get on with the real reason you're here. Click on the Go to App button to start building your resume!

reactiveResume.heading: Import from Reactive Resume
reactiveResume.text: Reactive Resume has its own schema format to make the most of all the customizable capabilities it has to offer. If you'd like to import a backup of your resume made with this app, just upload the file using the button below.

jsonResume.heading: Import from JSON Resume
jsonResume.text: JSON Resume is an open standard for resume schema structure. If you are one of the many enthusiasts who have their resume ready in this format, all it takes it just one click to get started with Reactive Resume.

linkedIn.heading: Import from LinkedIn
linkedIn.text: You can import a JSON that was exported from LinkedIn by clicking on the button below and selecting the appropriate file.

printDialog.heading: Use Browser's Print Dialog
printDialog.text: For those of you who want a quick solution, you need not look any further than your browser. All you have to do is press Ctrl/Cmd + P and open up the print dialog on your browser and get your resume printed immediately.

downloadPDF.heading: Download PDF
downloadPDF.text: These options allow you to print a single page, unconstrained version of your resume, perfect for those who have a lot of content. Alternatively, you could download a multi-page version of your resume as well with just one click.

jsonFormat.heading: Export to JSON Format
jsonFormat.text: You can also export your data into JSON format for safe keeping so that you can easily import it back into Reactive Resume whenever you want to edit or generate a resume.
